Thanks for addressing the issue!
From PR description, seems the problem is due to empty line
```
 key, value = line.lstrip().split(' ', 1)
ValueError: not enough values to unpack (expected 2, got 1)
, error:not enough values to unpack (expected 2, got 1)
```
So why not check if the line is empty and skip it if it is?

> Thanks for addressing the issue! From PR description, seems the problem is due to empty line
> 
> ```
> key, value = line.lstrip().split(' ', 1)
> ValueError: not enough values to unpack (expected 2, got 1)
> , error:not enough values to unpack (expected 2, got 1)
> ```
> 
> So why not check if the line is empty and skip it if it is?

Its not choking on an empty line. There is no empty line. Its choking on any line that doesn't have 2 spaces after the first non-whitespace character.
I see. Make sense to me.

For the T0 topo, it's explicitly set:
```
"src_port_lag_name": "Not Applicable" \
if topo_type in DOWNSTREAM_SERVER_TOPO else downstream_dest_lag_name[0],
```

@justin-wong-ce, I think this change will extend LACP time multiplier for all advanced-reboot (or upgrade path) cases.

Although that will not fail the test, but it is also excessive - we only need to extend the LACP retry count for the platforms where we do NOT trust the boot up process to be fast enough.
On newer platforms this should not be needed (yet).

Additionally the test should verify the behavior of the TOR devices in production. So if (for eg., 7260) upgrades w/o retry count extended it should be tested against that criteria during qualification stage.

> @justin-wong-ce, I think this change will extend LACP time multiplier for all advanced-reboot (or upgrade path) cases.
> 
> Although that will not fail the test, but it is also excessive - we only need to extend the LACP retry count for the platforms where we do NOT trust the boot up process to be fast enough. On newer platforms this should not be needed (yet).
> 
> Additionally the test should verify the behavior of the TOR devices in production. So if (for eg., 7260) upgrades w/o retry count extended it should be tested against that criteria during qualification stage.

Hmm the `ptftest` has no easy way of telling whether if the test is testing for `upgrade_path` or not - I can try checking by comparing `self.test_params['target_version']` vs the DUT's current version. Will post a follow up PR.

@vaibhavhd seems like there is no easy to determine if the test is doing `upgrade_path` testing from the PTF test's POV since `self.test_params['target_version']` is not populated. The current PTF test logic would do a version check if this field is populated, and skip the check if it is not populated (and probably for a good reason, since version names are not always consistent). We may also not want to always complete this check.

I think we have to introduce a new test param so the PTF test knows if it is doing a `upgrade_path` test or normal `advanced-reboot.py` test. Will that be okay?

@justin-wong-ce the issue here is that previously we used cEOS neighbors with 7260 (lacp multiplier 3) and sonic neighbors (lacp multiplier 5) for 7060 and Mellanox 2700. This gave us the tight lacp boundaries we needed for each platform.

Now with this change, ceos can be used for 7060 and 2700 with the same lacp multiplier 5 as sonic had, but the side-effect is that the timing boundary for 7260 has increased from 3 to 5 which we don't want.

This is not really a decision of the type of test (`upgrade_path` vs `platform_tests/advanced_reboot`) but rather, the platform + OS combo.

Previously, we had to make a decision to use sonic or ceos neighbors based on platform + OS and we did that by passing in the `--neighbor_type=sonic` cli arg. I think we should introduce a new cli arg called `--ceos_neighbor_lacp_multiplier` (for example) and plumb it through following the same path as `--neighbor_type` which will mean introducing a new ptf test param.

That way the test caller when they pick the testbed/dut and to/from versions they can also set the neighbor type to ceos and set the lacp multipiler too.

I see, sounds good.
I will add a new argument to pass into the ptftest and add a check to the test file to only set this argument when 7060 and 2700 is being tested.
@justin-wong-ce instead of hardcoding the 7060 and 2700 hwskus in the test scripts, can we have a CLI passed in from the top-level? (i.e. when triggering the sonic-mgmt test)

> @justin-wong-ce instead of hardcoding the 7060 and 2700 hwskus in the test scripts, can we have a CLI passed in from the top-level? (i.e. when triggering the sonic-mgmt test)

As in a new param defining lacp multiplier passed in from `sonic-mgmt/tests/run.sh`(via `-e`/extra params)?

Also, should `platform_tests/test_advanced_reboot.py` also use multiplier of 5 for 7060 and 2700, or only for upgrade_path?

The ipv4 test succeeds connecting from `VM101` src ip `100.1.0.29` -> `vlab-01` dst ip `10.1.0.32` which both of which are loopback ips on their respective nodes.

The ipv6 test fails connecting from `VM101` src ip `2064:100::1d` -> `vlab-01` dst ip `fc00:1::32` again, both of which are loopback ips on their respective nodes.

Now the difference appears to be that `vlab-0` is receiving the ipv4 return route as a `/32` to the single interface (`PortChannel101`)in which it originated. However, for the ipv6 route, the return route is a summarized `/64` route and which goes to any of the connected BGP peers on `PortChannel101-104`, thus the packet isn't routing out the right interface. Each of those peers have ip addresses in `2064:100::/64` like `2064:100::1d` and `2064:100::1e`. Each peer is also sharing the same ASN but aren't doing anything to share the real routes so it won't bounce from one host to another. Each route in `2064:100::/64` needs to be advertised as an individual `/128` instead.

why the pfcwd enabled can make the pcbb case to be flaky?

PCBB tests use pfc_gen.py to directly send long periods of XOFF to block data-traffic. At first, no WD is triggered since the queue is empty. Once data traffic starts entering, the WD triggers at around 200ms after the data transmission starts, which then drops the data. This can break the test depending on whether the data check operation was able to be performed within the PFC-WD window. 
This should also impact the other non-watermark-based tests (cisco skips those in favor of the watermark revision), unless PFC-WD isn't enabled there for some other reason.

Correction regarding what the actual issue here is:

`systemctl show {systemd_service} --timestamp unix -P ExecMainStartTimestamp` will return a Unix timestamp, which, by definition, is always based on 1/1/1970 00:00:00 UTC, regardless of what timezone the device is. This means that the number returned from the DUT isn't really attached to any time zone, which means the issue here isn't that the DUT is not on UTC, but instead the _sonic-mgmt container_ that is running these tests _is not on UTC_.

The `start_time` variable is using `datetime.datetime.now()`, which creates a timezone-unaware (or timezone naive) object, which also means it's in the local timezone. The timestamp that is returned by the `systemctl` command is passed through `datetime.datetime.utcfromtimestamp()`, which creates a timezone-aware object, with it being marked as being in the UTC timezone. Comparing these two objects then causes the issue, because Python is just going to do a direct number comparison, which is going to fail if sonic-mgmt isn't also on UTC.

There are two solutions to this:

1. When initializing `start_time`, use `datetime.datetime.now(datetime.timezone.utc)` instead to make it timezone-aware and make the timestamp object be in UTC.
2. Convert `start_time` to a Unix timestamp.

Either would've worked.

@yatishkoul , @YatishSVC-

There are two aspects to this PR:
1. Change the drop_percentage to be calculated for VOQ chassis by capturing pkt_drops on ingress interfaces.
2. Modification of pass-fail criteria for the drop_percentage. 

IMHO, these should be treated as two independent PRs. If required, we can always determine the order in which PRs will be merged in, which I don't think is the issue in this case.

For second item, I think there should be broader agreement between concerned teams about what should be range of the drop packets, ensuring that there is no false-pass introduced. I will recommend addressing ONLY item#1 in this PR and raise a new PR for item#2.

Tagging @vmittal-msft , @rawal01 to see if they think otherwise.

Hope you will agree to this.

Thanks,
-A
